question.title: Emojis won't show up properly in build logs for Maven Project name on Git Bash
question.body:
I have a pom file whose name looks similar to this.

<name>Some Name 😊</name>

But when I performed the maven build, I got this instead.

Some Name ≡ƒÖé

I set my project encoding to utf-8, as well as the reporting encoding. Here are my properties.

<properties>
    <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
    <project.reporting.outputEncoding>UTF-8</project.reporting.outputEncoding>
</properties>

I am using Windows 10 and Git Bash. I used the WindowsKey+; key combo to type the character. The character rendered correctly in both Notepad++ and Git Bash (when doing echo). But when I do a maven build in Git Bash, it just shows the messed up text above. I opened the pom file in Notepad++, and the file showed an encoding of UTF-8 on the bottom. I deleted and retyped the characters in Notepad++, in case my IDE was the problem, but no dice. I tried it on CMD, and I got the exact same output. Though, I should mention that, when I tried to do the echo command on CMD, I got 2 boxes with ?'s in them. So maybe CMD just can't do it to begin with. But Git Bash certainly can -- the echo command worked perfectly, but the maven output didn't work.

How do I get emoji's into my project name for my Maven build?

Here are the steps for a recreatable example.

  1. Make a new directory, then enter it.

  2. Copy the following text into a file called pom.xml.

      <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
       xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
       xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">

       <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

       <groupId>some.group</groupId>
       <artifactId>some.project</artifactId>
       <version>123</version>
       <packaging>pom</packaging>

       <name>Some Name 🙂</name>

 </project>

  3. Run the following command in the directory -- mvn clean.

  4. I get this bad output as one of the lines.

      [INFO] Building Some Name ≡ƒÖé 123

Please let me know if more info is needed.

answers.body:
There's two things at play here, as far as I know.

  1. The encoding used by the terminal.

  2. The encoding used by Java when printing to the standard output and error streams.

When a Java application is launched from a terminal it should be able to pick up/inherit the terminal's output encoding. However, when not launched from a terminal you may have to tell Java which encodings to use for its standard output and error streams, otherwise it will use the platform's defaults. With modern versions of Java (I believe 18+), you can do that with stdout.encoding and stderr.encoding system properties.

Examples (Windows 10/11)

Here's what worked for me on Windows 10/11 with CMD, PowerShell Core, and Git Bash. The following sample project was used with Java 24.0.1 and Maven 3.9.9.

The POM uses the exec-maven-plugin to execute the sample application. There are two executions: exec:java@app and exec:exec@app-forked. The first will execute the application in the same process as Maven and the second will fork the application in its own process. This is to show that how the Java application is launched affects the encoding it uses for its standard output and error streams.

In the CMD, PowerShell Core, and Git Bash examples below, the exec:exec@app-forked execution will always result in Hello, World! ? being printed instead of Hello, World! 🙂, regardless of encoding. At least, it did in my case. To have it print Hello, World! 🙂 when the terminal's encoding is UTF-8, uncomment the -Dstdout.encoding-UTF-8 argument in the execution's configuration.

Note I had the MAVEN_OPTS environment variable set to:

--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=allow --enable-native-access=ALL-UNNAMED

To avoid some warnings emitted by Maven's runtime when executing on Java 24.

All commands and their outputs are copy-pasted directly from the terminal (with some user-specific information omitted).

Sample Project

The POM and Java source files are saved with UTF-8 encoding.

pom.xml

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

  <groupId>com.example</groupId>
  <artifactId>app</artifactId>
  <version>0.1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>

  <name>MyApp 🙂</name>

  <properties>
    <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
    <maven.compiler.release>24</maven.compiler.release>
  </properties>

  <build>
    <plugins>
      <plugin>
        <groupId>org.codehaus.mojo</groupId>
        <artifactId>exec-maven-plugin</artifactId>
        <version>3.5.1</version>
        <executions>

          <!-- exec:java@app -->
          <execution>
            <id>app</id>
            <configuration>
              <mainClass>com.example.app.Main</mainClass>
            </configuration>
          </execution>

          <!-- exec:exec@app-forked -->
          <execution>
            <id>app-forked</id>
            <configuration>
              <executable>java</executable>
              <arguments>
                <!-- <argument>-Dstdout.encoding=UTF-8</argument> -->
                <argument>-cp</argument>
                <classpath/>
                <argument>com.example.app.Main</argument>
              </arguments>
            </configuration>
          </execution>

        </executions>
      </plugin>
    </plugins>
  </build>
</project>

Main.java:

package com.example.app;

public class Main {

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    System.out.println("Hello, World! 🙂");
  }
}

Command Prompt (CMD)

Used Windows Terminal.

Default Encoding

C:\...\emoji-test> chcp
Active code page: 437

C:\...\emoji-test> mvn compile exec:java@app exec:exec@app-forked
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
[INFO]
[INFO] --------------------------< com.example:app >---------------------------
[INFO] Building MyApp ? 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO]   from pom.xml
[INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]---------------------------------
[INFO]
[INFO] --- resources:3.3.1:resources (default-resources) @ app ---
[INFO] skip non existing resourceDirectory C:\...\emoji-test\src\main\resources
[INFO]
[INFO] --- compiler:3.13.0:compile (default-compile) @ app ---
[INFO] Nothing to compile - all classes are up to date.
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:java (app) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:exec (app-forked) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  1.248 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2025-07-01T18:57:45-06:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

UTF-8 Encoding

C:\...\emoji-test> chcp 65001
Active code page: 65001

C:\...\emoji-test> mvn compile exec:java@app exec:exec@app-forked
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
[INFO]
[INFO] --------------------------< com.example:app >---------------------------
[INFO] Building MyApp 🙂 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO]   from pom.xml
[INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]---------------------------------
[INFO]
[INFO] --- resources:3.3.1:resources (default-resources) @ app ---
[INFO] skip non existing resourceDirectory C:\...\emoji-test\src\main\resources
[INFO]
[INFO] --- compiler:3.13.0:compile (default-compile) @ app ---
[INFO] Nothing to compile - all classes are up to date.
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:java (app) @ app ---
Hello, World! 🙂
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:exec (app-forked) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  1.112 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2025-07-01T19:00:56-06:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

PowerShell Core 7.5.2

Used Windows Terminal.

Default Encoding

PS C:\...\emoji-test> chcp
Active code page: 437

PS C:\...\emoji-test> [Console]::OutputEncoding

IsSingleByte      : True
EncodingName      : OEM United States
WebName           : ibm437
HeaderName        : ibm437
BodyName          : ibm437
Preamble          :
WindowsCodePage   :
IsBrowserDisplay  :
IsBrowserSave     :
IsMailNewsDisplay :
IsMailNewsSave    :
EncoderFallback   : System.Text.InternalEncoderBestFitFallback
DecoderFallback   : System.Text.InternalDecoderBestFitFallback
IsReadOnly        : False
CodePage          : 437

PS C:\...\emoji-test> mvn compile exec:java@app exec:exec@app-forked
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
[INFO]
[INFO] --------------------------< com.example:app >---------------------------
[INFO] Building MyApp ? 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO]   from pom.xml
[INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]---------------------------------
[INFO]
[INFO] --- resources:3.3.1:resources (default-resources) @ app ---
[INFO] skip non existing resourceDirectory C:\...\emoji-test\src\main\resources
[INFO]
[INFO] --- compiler:3.13.0:compile (default-compile) @ app ---
[INFO] Nothing to compile - all classes are up to date.
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:java (app) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:exec (app-forked) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  1.304 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2025-07-01T19:11:47-06:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

UTF-8 Encoding

PS C:\...\emoji-test> chcp 65001
Active code page: 65001

PS C:\...\emoji-test> [Console]::OutputEncoding = [Text.Encoding]::UTF8

PS C:\...\emoji-test> mvn compile exec:java@app exec:exec@app-forked
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
[INFO]
[INFO] --------------------------< com.example:app >---------------------------
[INFO] Building MyApp 🙂 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO]   from pom.xml
[INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]---------------------------------
[INFO]
[INFO] --- resources:3.3.1:resources (default-resources) @ app ---
[INFO] skip non existing resourceDirectory C:\...\emoji-test\src\main\resources
[INFO]
[INFO] --- compiler:3.13.0:compile (default-compile) @ app ---
[INFO] Nothing to compile - all classes are up to date.
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:java (app) @ app ---
Hello, World! 🙂
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:exec (app-forked) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  1.098 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2025-07-01T19:13:27-06:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Note both the code page and [Console]::OutputEncoding were set to UTF-8.

Git Bash

Used Git Bash installed with Git version 2.50.0.windows.2.

First, I followed this answer to set the locale encodings in the terminal's options. That leads to the following output:

user@host MINGW64 /.../emoji-test
$ locale
LANG=
LC_CTYPE="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_NUMERIC="C.UTF-8"
LC_TIME="C.UTF-8"
LC_COLLATE="C.UTF-8"
LC_MONETARY="C.UTF-8"
LC_MESSAGES="C.UTF-8"
LC_ALL=

I'm not sure if that was necessary.

Second, I followed this answer (to the same question). It mentioned chcp.com, which seems to be the same as chcp used previously.

Default Encoding

user@host MINGW64 /.../emoji-test
$ chcp.com
Active code page: 437

user@host MINGW64 /.../emoji-test
$ mvn compile exec:java@app exec:exec@app-forked
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
[INFO]
[INFO] --------------------------< com.example:app >---------------------------
[INFO] Building MyApp ? 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO]   from pom.xml
[INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]---------------------------------
[INFO]
[INFO] --- resources:3.3.1:resources (default-resources) @ app ---
[INFO] skip non existing resourceDirectory C:\...\src\main\resources
[INFO]
[INFO] --- compiler:3.13.0:compile (default-compile) @ app ---
[INFO] Nothing to compile - all classes are up to date.
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:java (app) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:exec (app-forked) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  1.409 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2025-07-01T19:25:54-06:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Setting LANG to C.UTF-8 or en_US.UTF-8 didn't help.

UTF-8 Encoding

user@host MINGW64 /.../emoji-test
$ chcp.com 65001
Active code page: 65001

user@host MINGW64 /.../emoji-test
$ mvn compile exec:java@app exec:exec@app-forked
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
[INFO]
[INFO] --------------------------< com.example:app >---------------------------
[INFO] Building MyApp 🙂 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO]   from pom.xml
[INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]---------------------------------
[INFO]
[INFO] --- resources:3.3.1:resources (default-resources) @ app ---
[INFO] skip non existing resourceDirectory C:\...\emoji-test\src\main\resources
[INFO]
[INFO] --- compiler:3.13.0:compile (default-compile) @ app ---
[INFO] Nothing to compile - all classes are up to date.
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:java (app) @ app ---
Hello, World! 🙂
[INFO]
[INFO] --- exec:3.5.1:exec (app-forked) @ app ---
Hello, World! ?
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  1.263 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2025-07-01T19:28:44-06:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Though note in the terminal the 🙂 emoji had no color.

Remarks

Setting the active code page with chcp seems to be the common denominator. Though [Console]::OutputEncoding also had to be set for PowerShell Core.

I don't know if there's a system-wide way to set the default code page. For PowerShell you can create a profile script that sets the code page and output encoding. For Git Bash I believe you can add the config to your .bashrc file. Not sure about CMD.

Perhaps https://superuser.com/questions/269818/change-default-code-page-of-windows-console-to-utf-8 can help here.

question_comments.body: That's a good sign, It's a little difficult to know exactly what setup you have as there are subtly different git implementations on Windows. Some involve MINGW and its terminal, which might play a little more nicely with your locale settings. THIS could be of use
@g00se I get a whole bunch of key value pairs, with the values all being en_US.UTF-8 except for the LC_ALL key, which is blank. EDIT -- and the LANG key is blank too.

@g00se I'm glad it's working, but I'm not convinced that's the correct way to do things -- Agreed. But it's a start. Barring a better answer, I'd accept that. I feel like the right answer would involve just setting some setting in either Git Bash and/or CMD.
If you have git-bash installed, I think you should be able to execute the command locale. Can you - and what happens if you can?

@g00se That's making more sense. btw what's the output of chcp in cmd.exe? And of course, I mean in a fresh cmd.exe -- I opened a new CMD with admin, and just running chcp said Active code page: 437. Then, when I ran mvn clean, it actually gave me the garbled output above -- NOT the box with the question mark! Interesting. Then, I tried to do chcp 65001 and then mvn clean, and I went back to boxes with question marks in them.

It worked! For those following along, the command to punch into Git Bash was chcp.com 65001. Could you turn this into the answer? I'm glad it's working, but I'm not convinced that's the correct way to do things
That's making more sense. btw what's the output of chcp in cmd.exe? And of course, I mean in a fresh cmd.exe

@g00se Actually it would make more sense had we'd been given <name>Some Name 🙊</name> Are you sure it's not that, davidalayachew? -- To avoid any confusion, I made a fresh example, and only did copy paste. Please check my updated answer for a recreatable example and an exact output. EDIT -- though, I did have to send this over Outlook, so maybe that is part of the problem? I can't log on to this account for the machine this is happening on.

@Slaw This other answer may work better for Git Bash (for whatever reason, setting MAVEN_OPTS stopped working when trying it in a new window; not sure what I did differently). -- It worked! For those following along, the command to punch into Git Bash was chcp.com 65001. Could you turn this into the answer? Based on the discussions happening in the chat, we may suggest edits to include useful context about the problem. But just getting past the garbled output will be useful for many on its own.

@Slaw For Git Bash, I followed this answer but that didn't seem to be enough—though it may still be necessary. Additionally doing export MAVEN_OPTS="-Dstdout.encoding=UTF-8" led to Building MyApp 😊 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT being printed (except in the console the emoji has no color). Note I was testing with Java 24.0.1 and Maven 3.9.9. -- No dice. My set up was already configured with utf-8, and when I tried echo some emoji, it worked. But when trying maven clean, still got the messed up text from above.

@Slaw Doing [Console]::OutputEncoding = [Text.Encoding]::UTF8 for PowerShell Core and doing chcp 65001 for CMD led to Building MyApp 😊 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT being printed in both cases. -- I don't have Powershell Core, only Powershell and Powershell ISE. But tryinig in Powershell, I still got a box with a check mark in it. Same for your CMD way.
@g00se " It might be useful to post a link to a pom that reproduces the problem in part – " -- done. Please let me know if more info is needed.
Actually it would make more sense had we'd been given <name>Some Name 🙊</name> Are you sure it's not that, davidalayachew?

@g00se Even if some process were translating U+1F60A into U+1F642 (which seems unlikely), it wouldn’t change the fact that UTF-8 bytes are being printed by Maven, and they are not interpreted as UTF-8 in the console.
@VGR, the point is surely that we have to take into account the actual codepoint in the pom and then try to map it in some way to what is (erroneously) printed. But it doesn't map.

@g00se Your byte values do correspond to the character in the question (U+1F60A SMILING FACE WITH SMILING EYES), but the bytes being printed by Maven correspond to the character to which I’ve linked (U+1F642 SLIGHTLY SMILING FACE).
@VGR (the bytes which represent ≡ƒÖé in the MS-DOS CP437 character set) Wouldn't that be ≡ƒÿè ?
This other answer may work better for Git Bash (for whatever reason, setting MAVEN_OPTS stopped working when trying it in a new window; not sure what I did differently).

This is definitely a console/CMD problem, not a problem with your build or with Maven. The build is working perfectly: it is emitting the bytes F0 9F 99 82 (the bytes which represent ≡ƒÖé in the MS-DOS CP437 character set), which is the UTF-8 sequence for your emoji, code point 1f642.

For Git Bash, I followed this answer but that didn't seem to be enough—though it may still be necessary. Additionally doing export MAVEN_OPTS="-Dstdout.encoding=UTF-8" led to Building MyApp 😊 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT being printed (except in the console the emoji has no color). Note I was testing with Java 24.0.1 and Maven 3.9.9.
Doing [Console]::OutputEncoding = [Text.Encoding]::UTF8 for PowerShell Core and doing chcp 65001 for CMD led to Building MyApp 😊 0.1.0-SNAPSHOT being printed in both cases.
It might be useful to post a link to a pom that reproduces the problem in part
@g00se No dice -- I got boxes with a question mark in each one.
Try it using Powershell. Run this first [Console]::InputEncoding = [Console]::OutputEncoding = New-Object System.Text.UTF8Encoding
